importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news report indicates the most recent update on the flooding crisis, showing the ongoing impact and response efforts in Mexico.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The flooding events occurred over a period of one week, highlighting the duration and scale of the disaster.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to heavy rains and flooding in five states.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, reported 65 people still missing, with most in Hidalgo, Veracruz, and Puebla.
Veracruz reported 29 deaths, Hidalgo 21, Puebla 13, and Queretaro 1.
43 people are missing in Hidalgo, 18 in Veracruz, and 4 in Puebla.
Thousands of military personnel from the Army, Air Force, and National Guard have been deployed to deliver food, water, and aid to affected areas.
Early estimates show that about 100,000 houses have been severely affected, with some homes nearly destroyed by rising rivers.
The flooding was caused by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, which triggered rapid river rises and landslides.
The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul (Veracruz) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (Puebla), with 280mm and 286mm of rain, respectively.
Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of the electricity supply across the five states, where about 263,000 users lost power.
President Claudia Sheinbaum stated that there were no prior meteorological warnings indicating such extreme rainfall, raising questions about Mexico's early-warning systems.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Mexico has suffered severe flooding across five states—Veracruz, Hidalgo, Puebla, and Queretaro—due to heavy rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond. At least 64 people have died, with 65 still missing, and over 100,000 homes affected, many with rivers rising to dangerous levels. The heaviest rains occurred in Cerro Azul and Cuetzalan del Progreso, with 280mm and 286mm of precipitation respectively. The Mexican military, including the Army, Air Force, and National Guard, has been deployed to deliver food, water, and medical aid to isolated communities. Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of electricity to 263,000 affected users. President Claudia Sheinbaum and CNPC chief Laura Velazquez Alzua highlighted the lack of prior meteorological warnings, raising concerns about the effectiveness of Mexico’s early-warning systems in predicting extreme weather events.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
